["They originate from Australia and New Guinea, often colloquially referred to as 'down under'.", 'Use mosquito nets: Infected Anopheles mosquitoes are responsible for transmitting malaria between people, so sleeping under a long-lasting insecticidal net can prevent mosquito bites and stop transmission of the disease within households.', 'Indoor residual spraying (IRS): This involves indoor application of insecticides to kill or repel mosquitoes that enter human habitations, reducing malaria transmission.', 'Antimalarial drugs: Prophylactic antimalarial medication can be taken by people at risk of contracting the disease as a preventive measure', 'Environmental management: Reducing mosquito breeding sites, such as standing water bodies near human habitations can help control mosquito population densities and subsequently reduce malaria transmission.', 'Community education: Educating local populations about prevention measures like using insect repellents, wearing protective clothing, and seeking prompt medical care for symptoms of malaria contributes to the reduction in disease spread.', 'Early diagnosis and treatment: Promptly identifying cases through community-based surveillance systems and providing effective antimalarial treatments can reduce transmission by lowering parasite densities in human blood, which mosquitoes require for feeding.', 'Vaccine development: The RTS,S/AS01 malaria vaccine (Mosquirix) has been developed with partial efficacy and is being rolled out in some African countries to reduce the incidence of severe disease among children', 'Genetic modification: Recent advances include genetically modifying mosquitoes to either suppress their population or make them resistant to Plasmodium parasites (the cause of malaria).', 'Intermittent preventive treatment in pregnancy (IPTp): Administering antimalarial drugs during pregnancy can reduce the risk of maternal and newborn morbidity and mortality associated with malaria, which indirectly contributes to disease control efforts.']
